Award.AwardTitle: Student Support for the 2018 Federated Logic Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award supports the attendance of 35 US-based students to attend the seventh Federated Logic Conference (FLoC 18) which will be held in Oxford, United Kingdom, in July 2018. The federated logic conference is a large event which brings together nine major international conferences in the area of Formal Methods, and around 80 satellite workshops. While the participating conferences are normally held individually by their local conference organization on an annual basis, they all agree to this joint and federated event to be held every four years.

Enhancing the security, privacy, usability, and reliability of computing systems is widely accepted as one the grand challenges facing the computing-research community. Formal Methods have emerged as one of the primary approaches towards that goal. A federated conference provides an opportunity for accelerating research via synergy between the different strands of research in Formal Methods. Attending a large international conference with such diverse topical themes within this domain is a formative experience for graduate students, enabling them to build international collaborative relationships early in their research careers. Attending FLoC helps ensure that future generations of US scientists and engineers gain professional international research experiences early in their careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The seventh meeting (FLoC'18) was held in Oxford, UK, in July 2018. The following conferences participated in FLoC'18: the30th International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV), the 31st IEEE Computer Security FoundationsSymposium (CSF), the 35th International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP), the 9th International Joint Conferenceon Automated Reasoning (IJCAR), the 9th Conference on Interactive Theorem Proving (ITP), the 33rd ACM/IEEESymposium on Logic in Computer Science (LICS), the 3rd International Conference on Formal Structures for Computationand Deduction (FSCD), the 23rd International Symposium on Formal Methods (FM),and the 21st International Conference on Theory and Applications of Satisfiability Testing (SAT). In addition, close to 75satellite workshops were held at FLoC'18, as well as the 2nd School on Foundations of Programming and Software, Systems(FoPSS). This proposal requested funding to provide scholarships for US graduate students attending FLoC'18. FLoC'18 was attended by about 1986 participants, of which 555 were students.

Support funds were provided to selected students to cover expenses involved inattending the conference; 38 students were supported. (62 non-US students weresupported from other sources.) Of the 38 funded students, seven were female (and ofthose, three also identified as minorities) and 15 were male and identified asminorities.The supported students were able to participate in a unique meeting, whichtakes place only once in four years. All major researchers in computational logicparticipate in FLoC. The list of invited speakers at FLoC is a list of luminaries. Thestudents got exposed to cutting-edge research. They also got to meet numerousgraduate students from all over the world, establishing connections that would helpthem in launching their research careers. The reports from the students indicate thatthey found FLoC'18 to be a transformative experience.
